‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving, earlier approval comment below

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is what we call ascii ART, @Lisa-Has-Ideas has some competition with this entry, nicely done!

My approach to computing the surface area was the opposite of @Timinator, first I though it was really hard, then I realized I could 'just' flood fill it. (I am curious about how he did it without FF.)

Overall nice puzzle, with some interesting context and a straightforward solve.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really nice puzzle! Great great ASCII art!
It's first time that I see a flood fill in 3D, maybe someday in 4D ;)

my solution:
(ns Solution
  (:require [clojure.string :as str])
  (:gen-class))

(def dirs [[0 0 1] [0 0 -1] [0 1 0] [0 -1 0] [1 0 0] [-1 0 0]])
(defn vadd [v1 v2] (mapv + v1 v2))

(defn -main [& _]
  (let [[L W H] (map read-string (str/split (read-line) #" "))
        pad (vec (repeat (+ W 2) \o))
        padrow (vec (repeat (+ H 2) pad))
        mid (vec (repeatedly L #(->> (str/split (read-line) #" ")
                                     (map (fn [s] (str "o" s "o")))
                                     ((fn [s] (concat [pad] s [pad])))
                                     (mapv vec))))
        Map (atom (vec (concat [padrow] mid [padrow]))) ;Map [L H W]
        surface (atom 0)]
    (loop [todo [[0 0 0]]]
      (when (not-empty todo)
        (let [doing (first todo)]
          (if (not= \o (get-in @Map doing))
            (recur (rest todo))
            (do
              (swap! Map assoc-in doing \x)
              (recur (->> (map #(vadd doing %) dirs)
                          (filter #(= \o (get-in @Map %)))
                          (concat (rest todo)))))))))
    (doseq [y (range (inc L)) x (range (inc W)) z (range (inc H))
            :let [doing (get-in @Map [y z x]) need #{\x \#}]
            :when (contains? need doing)]
      (when (= need (set [(get-in @Map [(inc y) z x]) doing]))
        (swap! surface inc))
      (when (= need (set [(get-in @Map [y (inc z) x]) doing]))
        (swap! surface inc))
      (when (= need (set [(get-in @Map [y z (inc x)]) doing]))
        (swap! surface inc)))
    (let [fre (frequencies (flatten @Map))
          {solid \# inner \o} fre
          inner (if (nil? inner) 0 inner)
          act (/ @surface solid)
          den (/ solid (+ solid inner))]
      (println (format "%.4f" (float act)) (format "%.4f" (float den))))))

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very fun puzzle. I have to admit, I tried to make it way harder than needed by trying to use a flood fill to determine surface area. Only because of the medium classification did I think to look for an easier way. I like when a medium puzzle requires a bit more thought than I first expect.

Great writeup! Incredible ASCII art! The test case design is outstanding!

For the Python programmers, this is a very nice opportunity to practice using Numpy.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear and detailed statement, nice story around the underlying geometry problem, awesome ascii art in the description, so overall a high quality contribution.
When I opened it and first saw the ascii art, I thought "OMG, do we really need to draw this?". I was glad to see that No. The geometry calculation puzzle presented here is more interesting.

Hi, the ASCII art is impressive! 
I don't understand from the description if the outside of the solid is always a rectangular parallelepiped (so the area is simple to compute), and whether the problem is to correctly compute the inside volume. Thanks

Input
* Please mention that the slices are space-separated.

Cover picture
* Suggest to include an illustration of Example 1 in the cover picture, something like this (the thickness is wrong there, but you get the idea):

https://imgur.com/MVccTgP

Thanks.

Wow, that ASCII art illustration you added is awesome! üëçüèª

Well then you can have something else in the cover picture. üòÜ
It seems ASCII art has its limitations. Do the changes help?
What would be an appropriate tag for surface area?
If you like multidimensional flood fill, there is a 5D flood fill puzzle on codingame: https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/5d-chests :)
I will PM you. I too am curious how you did it will flood fill without running into the crazy complexity I ran into.

Wow, interesting~ I will try it.
Thanks a lot for the info!
I wouldn‚Äôt do any tags for surface area. I thought figuring out that part was the hardest part of the puzzle, but that might be just because I went down the wrong path initially.
Thanks, I was trying to follow your suggestion in a way that the image could be seen from the IDE.

Suggest to change "Critical flaw" (test) to be more similar to Validator 5 by changing a few of the hollow squares (the inside may be a smaller and flipped/rotated version of a pattern present in the validator).

Also don't forget the cover picture!

Thanks.
